arch:note.arch:string: The purpose of the daily journal was to record the activities taking place in a trench each day. This included which loci were excavated, how and why loci were excavated and the ongoing impressions of the relationships among loci. It should be noted that journals record the actions, impressions and ideas of trench supervisors during the excavations. They are not, therefore, the final interpretations or syntheses of the emerging data.

arch:internalDocument.arch:string:
Daily Trench Journal

Area F

Trench 7

July 8, 2002

Today we started in L7056 to remove the last part of the locus before closing it. In the northeast quadrant there were some carbon bits that we collected individually but put them in the same KT bags (based on their location in the locus). Those were KT #â€™s 8 and 9. After finishing this part of the trench we closed some loci, cleaned and re-evaluated our current position.

We closed loci 7047, 7056 and 7057. We had finished excavation on surface 7047 Saturday, 7/6/02, but officially closed it today. The fill beneath it is L7048.

After cleaning the trench, we reevaluated the loci and opened L7064 which is fill on the south of pit L7051 and the north of the burial. We also opened L7065 which is the ring of rocks/pottery in the center of the eastern half of the trench. It is notable that there is an animal bone in the center (possibly a goat). We also opened pit L7066. This is a small pit along the southern baulk. We also opened fill 7067 that consists of fill on the exterior of structure 7053 and 7068 which consists of fill on the interior of structure 7053.

After opening the loci, excavation began. We scraped L7048 and found an obsidian blade (KT#4). The exact location and elevation is on the dayplan for the day.

Cengis cut back the fill around the burial to better define the burial pit and give us more room to determine the course of the wall.

After cutting back a few cms., Cengis dug pit 7066. There was some strange matter I had not seen before. Dawnell thought it may be organic. We took samples of it and then we took a 2-liter sample for flotation. There did not appear to be any associated carbon with the pit.

Finally we started taking down elevation in L7064 and we hit a lot of pottery smashes. I plotted them all and took elevations.

Tomorrow we are going to lay a grid in the trench every 1 meter to aid in sample analysis. We may also take spider shots.
